user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_irq_ack:
```c
static void metal_uio_dev_irq_ack(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				 struct linux_device *ldev,
				 int irq)
{
	(void)lbus;
	(void)irq;
	int irq_info = 1;
	unsigned int val;
	int ret;

	ret = read(ldev->fd, (void *)&val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s, read uio irq fd %d failed: %d.\n",
						__func__, ldev->fd, ret);
		return;
	}
	ret = write(ldev->fd, &irq_info, sizeof(irq_info));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s, write uio irq fd %d failed: %d.\n",
						__func__, ldev->fd, errno);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_uio_dev_irq_ack:
struct linux_bus {
	struct metal_bus	bus;
	const char		*bus_name;
	struct linux_driver	drivers[MAX_DRIVERS];
	struct sysfs_bus	*sbus;
}
...
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I did not flag local non-pointer variables (unsigned int val; int irq_info; int ret;) because they are modified in this function (val receives data from read(), irq_info is written and used as the data to acknowledge the IRQ), so they must be non-const. The cast to (void *)&val and the buffer passed to read() must be mutable because read() writes into the buffer. The write() call accepts a const void * argument (so passing &irq_info, a non-const pointer, is allowed and appropriate). The member bus_name is already const-qualified (const char *), so it does not need investigation. The drivers field is an array of structs (not a pointer) and therefore not relevant to rule 8.13. Fields such as the integer fd and the use of errno are not pointer-type issues under this rule. Other code fragments not listed either already use const where appropriate or involve objects that must remain non-const because they are written to.
